pr_title: Switch Trace and Span id from BigInteger to DDId

timeline.bodyText: Since this is used for tests, can we make it package private or private instead?
timeline.author: devinsba

replies.bodyText: It's used for tests from all over the place, but I could also remove it and change the tests to use DDId.from(1) instead.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: Groovy will automatically do the reflection required to access the field. I'm not sure that it isn't used in the couple Java tests that exist though
replies.author: devinsba

replies.bodyText: Thanks, didn't know that.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: I think the 2 argument nextLong would be correct here. We do support negative signed longs
timeline.author: devinsba

replies.bodyText: Yes, I wasn't sure if there was any other reason than BigInteger not handling a negative long the right way. I'll change it.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: The old behaviour was to generate a 63 bit, so positive, identifier though.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: I'll keep this as it was before to minimize the materialization of BigInteger, with a comment that it can be changed when msgpack is fixed.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: Do we really need this? It will be extremely rare to overflow, can't we just materialise when (if) we do
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Also, we will only ever need it once, so caching is questionable?
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Can't we need it multiple times? I mean the ParentId could be used multiple times.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText:
Yes, that can happen, but if the parent span of several spans is remote, the ids won't have been deduplicated.
If the parent is in process, the parent id will be the same instance, but until now we generated 63 bit span identifiers, so know we won't need the BigInteger.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText:
Yes, the 63 bit ids makes sure this doesn't happen for our ids. I'll keep it that way.
So we never start more than one span inside a span coming from the outside, but it might have a trace id that has this characteristic, and that will get reused as far as I can see. Can we leave this in until we fix msgpack? It's not that common that it will drag a BigInteger with it, and right now it bumps the object from 40 to 48 bytes on ZGC, and is a lost 4 bytes on G1?
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: The cast is unnecessary here, >>> will shift zero into the high bits
timeline.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: Could just mask with 0xFFFFFFFFL to isolate the low bits.
timeline.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: mask unnecessary here if cast above is removed.
timeline.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: mask unnecessary if just shifted right above without casting on line 200
timeline.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: I wonder should we be shifting the high bits right and xoring?
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Yes, we should probably.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: Just call java.lang.Long#hashCode(long)?
replies.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Well, that was 1.8, so I'll do the shift/xor thing.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: maybe add a comment that the race condition is benign
timeline.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we will ever need this except at the last possible moment when we serialise
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Yes, it's only there AFAIK.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: Should we submit a PR for packUnsignedLong?
replies.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Yes I can do that (I already have a fork).
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: can we take this off the critical path by marking it in a bitmask and checking the bitmask against zero (meaning valid) at the end?
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Sure, we can just or together the ds, and if it's negative at the end it's broken. No need to say exactly which c is wrong.
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: even better than what I had in mind
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: Can this be implemented the same way as JDK8 Long.compareUnsigned(i.e. add Long.MIN_VALUE to each side?
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: I'll take a look at it.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: I believe this is the only time DDId.toBigInteger is called.
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Correct.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: Same comment here about the race condition.
timeline.author: tylerbenson

timeline.message: DDId changes based on review comments
DDId changes based on review comments
DDId changes based on review comments
DDId changes based on review comments

timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText:
I don't really trust javac to be smart so I load up the this.id field first, and then use it twice in the calculation below. I double checked the generated byte code, and if I don't do this it will read up the this.id field from the object twice. That double read will most likely be optimized away at some point, but it can't hurt to be proactive.
With local variable               | Without local variable
----------------------------------|----------------------------------
public int hashCode();            | public int hashCode();
  Code:                           |   Code:
   0: aload_0                     |    0: aload_0
   1: getfield  #14 // Field id:J |    1: getfield  #14 // Field id:J
   4: lstore_1                    |    4: aload_0
   5: lload_1                     |    5: getfield  #14 // Field id:J
   6: lload_1                     |    8: bipush    32
   7: bipush    32                |   10: lushr
   9: lushr                       |   11: lxor
  10: lxor                        |   12: l2i
  11: l2i                         |   13: ireturn
  12: ireturn                     |
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.message: Switch Trace and Span id from BigInteger to DDId
DDId changes based on review comments
